questions.text: Malignant features of breast lesions on ultrasound are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hyperechogenic

A malignant breast lesion on ultrasound typically presents as hypoechogenic (darker) compared to the surrounding breast tissue due to its dense cellularity and different acoustic properties. Conversely, hyperechogenicity (brighter than surrounding tissue) is generally associated with benign lesions, such as some types of cysts or fibroadenomas, rather than malignant ones.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, headache, confusion and seizures. Diagnostic CSF investigations showed decresed glucose, increased protein and lymphocytosis in the CSF. His CEMR image is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tubercular meningitis

This is the classic presentation for TBM. The CSF profile in TBM commonly shows decreased glucose, increased protein, and lymphocytic pleocytosis. The CEMR image, while not explicitly described in detail in the prompt, often shows characteristic findings in TBM, such as basal meningeal enhancement and sometimes hydrocephalus or tuberculomas, due to the thick exudate that forms in the basal cisterns. This combination of clinical symptoms, CSF findings, and typical imaging features makes TBM the most probable diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct temporal sequence for the appearance of the stated radiation effect on peripheral blood components?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lymphocytopenia, granulocytopenia, thrombocytopenia, anemia 

Lymphocytes are the most radiosensitive cells in the peripheral blood because they are highly active in the immune system and are in various stages of division. Even low doses of radiation can induce apoptosis in lymphocytes. Their normal lifespan varies, but the effects of radiation on these sensitive cells are seen very rapidly, within hours to days.

questions.text: The following sign is seen in —
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

PKAN 

Appearance shown is Eye of tiger appearance in the area of globus pallidus seen in hallevorden Spatz disease aka PKAN.

questions.text: Identify the finding seen:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diverticulosis 

Appearance shown is saw tooth appearance of Diverticulosis

questions.text: Identify the following structure marked with asterisk
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Concha bullosa

Concha bullosa is the pneumatization (air-filling) of the middle nasal turbinate, which can be seen as an air-filled cavity within the turbinate on CT imaging.

In the image, the middle turbinate appears expanded and contains air, which is characteristic of concha bullosa.

questions.text: Screening investigation of choice for carotid stenosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Doppler USG

Doppler Ultrasound (USG) is the first-line, non-invasive, cost-effective, and widely available test used to screen for carotid artery stenosis.

It provides information about:

Degree of stenosis

Blood flow velocity

Plaque morphology

questions.text: The radiologist wears ................ to KNOW the amount of exposure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Thermoluminescent Dosimeter (TLD)

Thermoluminescent Dosimeter (TLD) is a personal radiation monitoring device used by healthcare workers, including radiologists, to measure cumulative radiation exposure over time.

It contains crystals (commonly lithium fluoride) that store energy when exposed to ionizing radiation.

When heated, these crystals release light proportional to the radiation dose received.

This allows accurate measurement of the amount of radiation exposure.

questions.text: A 34 year old male complaints of lower back pain since six months. He is previously diagnosed as a case of ulcerative disease of colon, X-ray picture of lumbar spine given. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ankylosing Spondylitis

The X-ray image shows the "bamboo spine" appearance — a classic radiological finding in Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS).

Bamboo spine: Straightening and squaring of vertebral bodies with ossification of:

Annulus fibrosus (outer fibers of intervertebral discs)

Syndesmophytes (thin vertical bone spurs bridging vertebrae)

Ossification of spinal ligaments, especially the anterior longitudinal ligament.

Fusion of sacroiliac joints (sacroiliitis) is also commonly seen on pelvic films.

Clinical Clues:

Young male (common age: 15–40 years)

Chronic inflammatory back pain >3 months

History of ulcerative colitis → indicates seronegative spondyloarthropathy association

Morning stiffness, improves with exercise

questions.text: Focal and diffuse thickening of gallbladder wall with high amplitude reflections and ‘comet tail’ artifacts on USG as shown suggest the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Adenomyomatosis

Focal or diffuse gallbladder wall thickening

Echogenic foci within the wall

Characteristic “comet tail” artifacts (reverberation artifacts)

These findings are classic for adenomyomatosis of the gallbladder

A benign hyperplastic condition involving the gallbladder wall

Caused by proliferation of mucosal epithelium and formation of intramural Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses

Can be focal, segmental, or diffuse

Ultrasound Findings:

Comet tail artifacts: due to cholesterol crystals within Rokitansky-Aschoff sinuses

May show ring-down artifacts

questions.text: All lung carcinomas for diagnosis requires CECT thorax but MRI is useful in which of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pancoast tumor

MRI is particularly useful in Pancoast tumors because these tumors arise at the lung apex and often invade adjacent soft tissues such as the brachial plexus, subclavian vessels, vertebral bodies, and spinal canal. While CECT thorax is used for general lung cancer diagnosis and staging, MRI provides superior soft tissue resolution, making it ideal for assessing the extent of local invasion in Pancoast tumors. This helps in precise preoperative planning and determining resectability.

questions.text: Mount Fuji sign is seen in which of the following condition:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tension Pneumocephalus

The Mount Fuji sign is a classic CT finding seen in tension pneumocephalus, a condition where air accumulates under pressure in the cranial cavity, usually after head trauma or neurosurgery. The sign refers to the separation and compression of the frontal lobes by subdural air, resembling the twin peaks of Mount Fuji. This finding indicates mass effect and raised intracranial pressure, requiring urgent intervention. It is specific to tension pneumocephalus and helps differentiate it from simple pneumocephalus.

questions.text: Identify the abnormality found in the ultrasound image shown:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Phrygian cap

A folded appearance at the fundus of the gallbladder, which is characteristic of a Phrygian cap. This is a normal anatomical variant where the gallbladder fundus folds over itself, resembling the shape of the soft, conical cap worn in ancient Phrygia (modern-day Turkey). It is benign, asymptomatic, and does not require treatment. Recognizing this variant is important to avoid mistaking it for a pathological condition like a septum or mass.

questions.text: Shown finding on USG is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Spina bifida

The ultrasound image shows the "lemon sign", which is seen as indentation of the frontal bones of the fetal skull, giving it a shape resembling a lemon. This sign is commonly associated with spina bifida, particularly in the second trimester. It results from decreased intracranial pressure due to the open spinal defect, causing the skull to collapse inward anteriorly. The lemon sign is an important indirect marker of neural tube defects, especially in screening for open spina bifida.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man has been experiencing worsening headaches and new-onset seizures. MRI with contrast was done and is given. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Glioblastoma

A heterogeneous, irregular, ring-enhancing lesion with central necrosis and surrounding edema, crossing the midline—classic for glioblastoma multiforme (GBM). GBM is the most aggressive primary brain tumor, commonly presenting in older adults with symptoms like headache, seizures, and neurological deficits. Its hallmark imaging features include butterfly appearance, central necrosis, and enhancement after contrast, reflecting its infiltrative and necrotic nature.

questions.text: Which of the following modalities use remote afterloading?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Brachytherapy

Remote afterloading is a technique used in brachytherapy, where a radioactive source is placed into or near the tumor using applicators, and the source is loaded after the applicator is positioned—remotely, via a machine. This method enhances safety for healthcare workers, as it minimizes radiation exposure during source placement. It is commonly used in cancers like cervical, endometrial, and prostate cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations is best to detect calcification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CT

CT (Computed Tomography) is the best imaging modality for detecting calcifications due to its high spatial resolution and excellent contrast for different tissue densities. Calcifications appear as hyperdense (bright) areas on CT scans and are easily distinguished from surrounding soft tissues. CT is more sensitive than X-ray and ultrasound, and much better than MRI, where calcifications may not be clearly visualized

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with history of 4 weeks of immobilization for fracture femur developed sudden onset of chest pain and hemoptysis. ECG shows S1 Q3 T3 pattern with shown radiological finding. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pulmonary embolism

A CT pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) demonstrating a filling defect in the pulmonary artery, which is classic for pulmonary embolism (PE). The clinical scenario — a young male with prolonged immobilization (risk factor), sudden chest pain, hemoptysis, and S1Q3T3 pattern on ECG — further supports the diagnosis. The filling defect represents a thrombus obstructing blood flow in the pulmonary circulation, confirming acute PE.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with weight loss, intermittent low-grade fever and back pain. A lumbar spine MRI was done, after reviewing the findings contrast was injected and shown finding was observed. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pott’s spine

Destruction of adjacent vertebral bodies

Intervertebral disc involvement

Prevertebral or paravertebral soft tissue component or abscess

Collapse or wedging of vertebral bodies with gibbus deformity

The clinical history of back pain, weight loss, and low-grade fever strongly supports a chronic infectious process like tuberculosis. 

Unlike metastasis or degenerative disease, Pott's spine typically involves the anterior part of the vertebral body and spans multiple vertebrae with disc involvement. Contrast enhancement further highlights inflammatory or abscess components.

questions.text: A woman presented with confusion, constipation, and headache. Her serum calcium level was 13.1 mg/dL, and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) was elevated. She was diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which imaging modality is preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sestamibi scan

The preferred imaging modality for localizing parathyroid adenomas in primary hyperparathyroidism is the sestamibi scan (technetium-99m sestamibi scintigraphy). It is a nuclear medicine scan that detects hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue based on increased mitochondrial activity and blood flow. This helps guide minimally invasive parathyroidectomy. It is more sensitive and specific than CT, MRI, or FDG PET for identifying parathyroid adenomas, especially when ALP is elevated, indicating increased bone turnover.

questions.text: A patient arrives at the emergency department experiencing seizures, confusion, and a headache. He has a history of chronic ear infections and underwent a CT scan immediately. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Temporal lobe abscess

A ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding hypodense edema in the temporal lobe, consistent with a brain abscess. The patient's history of chronic ear infections (otitis media or mastoiditis) strongly suggests spread of infection to the temporal lobe, which is a common site due to proximity. Symptoms like seizures, headache, and confusion are typical of a space-occupying lesion like an abscess. The well-defined ring enhancement is due to capsule formation, which helps distinguish abscess from other lesions such as tumors or infarcts.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man presents with confusion. He takes antihypertensive medication and aspirin following a recent myocardial infarction. He remembers a minor fall from a chair three weeks ago, but his neurological exam is otherwise normal. Diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Chronic subdural hematoma

A crescent-shaped hypodense (dark) collection over the cerebral hemisphere, consistent with a chronic subdural hematoma. This typically occurs in elderly patients after minor trauma, especially those on antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy, like aspirin. The delayed onset of confusion and the history of a fall weeks ago support the diagnosis. Over time, acute blood becomes hypodense due to liquefaction, leading to the typical appearance seen here.

questions.text: Interventional radiology Procedure used for Aneurysm
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Coiling

This is a common interventional radiology procedure used to treat aneurysms, particularly intracranial aneurysms.
It involves the insertion of detachable coils into the aneurysm sac via a catheter, which promotes thrombosis and prevents rupture.
Sclerotherapy: Typically used for treating vascular malformations or varicose veins, not aneurysms.

Bare stent: Stents are used in vascular procedures, but for aneurysms, "stent-assisted coiling" (using a stent to support coils) might be used. A bare stent alone is not commonly employed for aneurysm treatment.

questions.text: Ga-68PSMA is used to diagnose which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prostate cancer

Ga-68 PSMA (Gallium-68 Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen) is a radiotracer used in PET/CT imaging. It targets the Prostate-Specific Membrane Antigen (PSMA), a protein highly expressed in prostate cancer cells. This imaging technique is commonly employed for the detection, staging, and recurrence monitoring of prostate cancer.

questions.text: A delayed intravenous urogram of the patient is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?+
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pelviuretric junction obstruction

The delayed intravenous urogram (IVU) shows a grossly dilated renal pelvis and calyces with a smooth outline and no contrast passing beyond the pelviureteric junction. This "ballooned" appearance is characteristic of Pelviureteric Junction (PUJ) Obstruction, where the flow of urine is blocked at the junction between the renal pelvis and the ureter. As a result, urine accumulates in the renal pelvis, leading to hydronephrosis.

questions.text: Identify the segment marked in orange
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

5

To understand the segments on CT abdomen

questions.text: Patient with nasal discharge and mild dyspnea.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Kartagener

The images depict key features consistent with Kartagener syndrome, a subset of primary ciliary dyskinesia. The chest X-ray shows dextrocardia, the sinus X-ray reveals chronic sinusitis, and the CT scan demonstrates bilateral bronchiectasis. These findings, along with the patient’s symptoms of nasal discharge and mild dyspnea, confirm the classic triad of Kartagener syndrome: chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis, and situs inversus. The underlying cause is defective ciliary motility, leading to impaired mucociliary clearance and recurrent respiratory infections.

choices.text: Small cell cancer of the cancer

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who presents with ptosis and muscle weakness was found to improve on rest. She complains of dysphagia and has engorged veins on the thorax. Using the CT scan image below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Thymoma

The CT scan shows an anterior mediastinal mass, which is the classic location for a thymoma. The patient's symptoms—ptosis, muscle weakness that improves with rest, and dysphagia—are hallmark features of myasthenia gravis, an autoimmune disorder frequently associated with thymoma. The engorged thoracic veins may be due to compression from the mass. Other options like Pancoast tumor or small cell lung cancer typically present with different mass locations and symptom profiles

questions.text: A 6 week child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of recurrent Vomiting. The vomiting's were projectile and non-bilious. Identify the condition using the radiograph below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CHPS

A thickened, elongated pyloric muscle with a narrowed pyloric canal, consistent with CHPS. The clinical scenario describes a 6-week-old infant with projectile, non-bilious vomiting, which is the classic presentation. This condition results from hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter, causing gastric outlet obstruction. On ultrasound, the “target sign” or “donut sign” is typically seen in transverse views, and the elongation of the pyloric canal is seen in longitudinal views. This presentation, combined with the ultrasound findings, confirms the diagnosis of CHPS.

questions.text: Foreign body in esophagus xray and name of the sign
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Double ring sign

The X-ray shows a round, radio-opaque object located in the midline over the thoracic inlet, consistent with a foreign body in the esophagus. The “double ring sign” (also called the halo sign) is characteristic of a coin lodged in the esophagus, where the face of the coin is visible as two concentric rings due to its flat orientation. This differentiates it from a coin in the trachea, which would typically show a linear edge on frontal view. This finding confirms esophageal location and the diagnosis of a swallowed coin.

questions.text: The chest x-ray of a child who presented with progressive breathlessness is given. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Tetralogy of Fallot

A classic "boot-shaped heart" (also called coeur en sabot), which is highly suggestive of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). This appearance is due to right ventricular hypertrophy, leading to an upturned cardiac apex, and concavity of the pulmonary artery segment due to pulmonary stenosis. Additionally, there is decreased pulmonary vascularity on the X-ray, consistent with reduced pulmonary blood flow—another hallmark of TOF. These radiographic findings, along with a clinical history of progressive breathlessness or cyanotic spells in a child, confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: 30 year old with BMI 18 with progressive difficulty in swallowing in both solids and liquids for 8 months. Barium swallow is shown to you. What other investigation should be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

UGI endoscopy + Manometry

This is classic picture of achalasia cardia

Manometry is indicated for confirmation of diagnosis.

Achalasia: barium swallow study may be used to confirm oesophageal dilatation, in addition to assessing for mucosal abnormalities. 

Findings include:

Bird beak sign or rat tail sign

Oesophageal dilatation

Tram track appearance: central longitudinal lucency bounded by barium on both sides

Incomplete lower oesophageal sphincter relaxation that is not coordinated with oesophageal contraction

Pooling or stasis of barium in the oesophagus when the oesophagus has become atonic or non-contractile (a late feature in the disease)

Uncoordinated, non-propulsive, tertiary contractions

choices.text: EDH after rebleeding into the clot

questions.text: Swirl sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

EDH after rebleeding into the clot

EDH ie extradural haemorrhage is acollection of blood between the calvaria and periosteal layer of duramater 

EDH arehyperdense biconvex in shape when seen on NCCT and they strip the dura away from periosteum of skull as they expand. 

EDH doesnot cross suture lines

The presence of a hypodense component (swirl sign) is seen in about 1/3rd of patients and indicates active re-bleeding with unretracted clot 

EDH compresses the underlying subarachnoid space and displace cortex medially bucklin the grey-white matter interface inward  [Osborn brain 2E]

questions.text: 35 years old male, expansile swelling of distal forearm, near wrist joint. Xray Show
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

GCT

The clinical image shows a visible swelling near the wrist joint, and the X-ray reveals a well-defined, expansile, lytic lesion at the distal end of the radius extending up to the subarticular region without a sclerotic rim. This is characteristic of a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT), which typically occurs in adults between 20–40 years and usually involves the epiphysis of long bones, commonly the distal radius. The lesion appears eccentric and expansile with thinning of the cortex, features that help differentiate it from other bone tumors like Ewing’s sarcoma or osteochondroma.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about MRCP?

1. MRI is used to obtain the images

2. Intraenous gadolinium is used.

3. It shows the biliary tree

4. Dye has to be injected endoscopically

5. It is an invasive procedure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

1+3

Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) is a non-invasive imaging technique to visualise the intra and extrahepatic biliary tree and pancreatic ductal system. The technique exploits the ﬂuid which is present in the biliary and pancreatic ducts as an intrinsic contrast medium by acquiring the images using heavily T2 weighted sequences. Since the ﬂuid-ﬁlled structures in the abdomen have a long T2 relaxation time as compared to the surrounding soft tissue, these structures appear hyperintense against the surrounding non-ﬂuid-containing tissues on a heavily T2 weighted sequence and can easily be distinguished.

questions.text: 37 year-old female patient who is HIV positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pneumocystis pneumonia

Pneumocystis pneumonia typically shows perihilar or diffuse distribution. It is more severe in upper lung zones of patients on pentamidine aerosol prophylaxis. Patients may have pneumatoceles that typically develop in the periphery of upper lobes. Curiously, pneumatoceles are only seen in those with HIV infection. Pneumocystic pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic fungal infection that often affects individuals with T-cell immunodeﬁciency. The causative organism has been renamed Pneumocystis jiroveci. The most common imaging manifestation is ground-glass opacities that are perihilar or diffuse. If untreated, PCP evolves into a consolidative appearance. Appropriately treated PCP (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole or intravenous pentamidine) carries a very good prognosis with a 90% survival rate.

questions.text: What is the LEAST useful imaging study for detection of pneumoperitoneum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Supine abdominal radiograph

Free air within the peritoneal cavity rises to the least dependent portion of the abdomen and is usually evident on upright abdominal and chest ﬁlms, decubitus ﬁlms of the abdomen, and abdominal CT. Only large amounts of free air are detectible on supine abdominal ﬁlms

questions.text:
A patient is being evaluated for recurrent urinary tract infections. His abdominal CT scan is shown below-

Which of the following most likely  prevented  the  proper  ascent  of  the  anomalous  organ  seen  on the CT scan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Inferior mesenteric artery

A horseshoe kidney, which is a congenital fusion anomaly where the lower poles of the kidneys are joined. This condition often leads to impaired kidney ascent during embryologic development. The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) is the primary structure that prevents the horseshoe kidney from ascending to its normal position, as it lies anterior to the fused isthmus.

Patients with horseshoe kidneys are prone to recurrent urinary tract infections, hydronephrosis, and renal calculi due to impaired drainage and positioning, as seen in this case.

questions.text: Diagnosis in xray shown is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Chronic Osteomyelitis

The X-ray images display features highly suggestive of Chronic Osteomyelitis. The left image shows significant periosteal reaction (white arrowhead) and an area of lucency with sclerosis (white arrow), indicating bone destruction and new bone formation, characteristic of chronic infection. The right image further highlights the irregular bone changes, including areas of both increased and decreased density (black arrowheads and white arrow), consistent with ongoing inflammatory and reparative processes within the bone due to chronic infection. These findings are classic for osteomyelitis, unlike the aggressive patterns seen in sarcomas or the more organized new bone formation of callus.

choices.text: Apical segment of Right lower lobe consolidation
Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of fever and cough for the past 3-5 days. His examination findings findings reveal crepitations. Chest xray is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Right middle lobe consolidation

The chest xray shows opacities with obscuration of the right cardiac border is suggestive of right middle lobe consolidation. The loss of clear demarcation between the normal lung and its surrounding soft structures is called the silhouette sign. It occurs due to loss of contrast between lungs and soft tissue when the lung parenchyma is no longer filled with air

questions.text: Shown finding in a 50 year old male with poor balance, posture, and frequent falls with tremors having shown radiological finding is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Multiple system atrophy

The MRI image shows significant atrophy of the pons and cerebellum, particularly the "hot cross bun" sign, which is a cruciform hyperintensity on T2-weighted images within the pons. This specific radiological finding, combined with the clinical presentation of a 50-year-old male with poor balance, posture, frequent falls, and tremors, is highly characteristic of Multiple System Atrophy (MSA), specifically the MSA-P (parkinsonian) or MSA-C (cerebellar) subtypes. While other conditions can cause cerebellar or brainstem atrophy, the "hot cross bun" sign is a strong indicator for MSA.

questions.text: USG of a neonate who is being evaluated for urinary abnormalities reveals the presence of shown finding. What is the investigation of choice for confirming the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

MCU (Micturating CystoUrethrogram)

The ultrasound image of the neonate shows dilated renal pelvis and calyces, consistent with hydronephrosis. This finding in a neonate being evaluated for urinary abnormalities raises suspicion for vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) or an obstructive uropathy, such as posterior urethral valves. To confirm the presence and assess the severity of vesicoureteral reflux, the Micturating CystoUrethrogram (MCU) is the gold standard investigation. It involves filling the bladder with contrast and taking X-ray images during voiding to visualize the flow of urine and detect any reflux into the ureters and kidneys

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given MRI scan:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cerebellum

The provided MRI scan is a sagittal view of the brain. The red arrow points to the structure located at the back of the brain, inferior to the cerebrum and posterior to the brainstem. This convoluted structure, responsible for coordinating voluntary movements, balance, and posture, is the Cerebellum. The midbrain, brainstem, and cerebrum are distinct parts of the brain located elsewhere.

questions.text: Identify the sign demonstrated in the given image:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stratosphere sign

The ultrasound image shows a barcode-like or "Stratosphere sign" on M-mode, where the normal granular appearance of the lung parenchyma ("seashore sign") is lost. This occurs due to the absence of lung sliding, a key finding in pneumothorax, where the visceral and parietal pleura are no longer in contact, preventing the usual dynamic motion.

questions.text: The image given below shows the MRI of the knee. Identify the marked structure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

PCL

The provided MRI scan is a sagittal view of the knee. The white arrow points to a ligament deep within the knee joint, running from the posterior aspect of the intercondylar fossa of the tibia to the lateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle. This anatomical location and orientation are characteristic of the Posterior Cruciate Ligament (PCL). The ACL (Anterior Cruciate Ligament) runs in the opposite direction, while the MCL (Medial Collateral Ligament) and Patellar tendon are located more superficially and anteriorly/medially respectively.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child was brought to your hospital having recurrent attacks of pain abdomen.OE: sausage shaped mass was palpable in the right lumbar region. Barium enema finding is shown. What is the diagnosis on the basis of barium enema findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intussusception

The clinical presentation of a 10-month-old child with recurrent abdominal pain, a palpable sausage-shaped mass in the right lumbar region, and the given barium enema finding are highly characteristic of Intussusception. The barium enema image likely shows the classic "coiled spring" appearance, which is pathognomonic for intussusception, where one segment of the intestine telescopes into another. This condition is a common cause of intestinal obstruction in infants and young children, and a barium enema is often both diagnostic and therapeutic.

questions.text: Which part of the bowel is dilated in the Xray shown?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Jejunum

On a normal barium study of the small bowel, the jejunum is located in the upper left abdomen and the ileum in the lower right abdomen, to be continued by the colon in the ileocecal region. This configuration must be shown in any series of the small intestine. There is no definite border between jejunum and ileum, however, more than half of the small bowel is ileum.

The mucosa of the small bowel is characterized by the existence of the valvulae conniventes (also referred to as Kerkrin valves or circular folds). These folds start from the second part of the duodenum, which has a greater number of them, and they decrease in number as the small bowel approaches the ileocecal valve. With gaseous distension of the bowel loops, they are never completely effaced in the jejunum but they may be effaced in the ileum.

questions.text: A 34 year old female presents with features of hyperthyroidism. A thyroid scan was done and is shown. What can be the likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thyroiditis

Thyroiditis: Low uptake thyroid scan in patients with hyperthyroidism is almost diagnostic, in appropriate clinical setting and ultrasound findings. Correct diagnosis is important as treatment with radioiodine is contraindicated in these patients - it is a self-limiting disease.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis is this patient with joint pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lupus

Classic features: deformity without erosions.

Mimic: Jacoud arthropathy

questions.text: MRI brain of a 30 year old patient is shown. She has blurring of vision with painful eye movements. What is Investigation of choice for eye pathology evaluation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

MRI orbit with contrast

MRI image shows dawson fingers and suggesting multiple sclerosis. Hence in orbit we are looking for Optic Neuritis- for which CEMR is the IOC. On imaging, optic neuritis is most easily identified as a unilateral optic nerve swelling, with high T2 signal and contrast enhancement
